results.title: Godzilla
results.creator_credit: Dean Devlin, Centropolis Pictures and Roland Emmerich
results.brief_description: Perhaps one of the world’s most famous and enduring characters, Godzilla first appeared on Japanese screens in the 1954 release “Gojira”. In this version, the monster lizard has been created on a remote island somewhere in the South Pacific by nuclear testing, and she is heading to America, land of plenty, to hatch her offspring. Fantastic special effects make this the ultimate monster movie - a 20 story tall lizard with one thing on her mind.

results.title: Godspeed Verticals
results.brief_description: A dual screen digital video installation, “Godspeed Verticals” explores BMX bicycle riding and skateboarding and its relations to and functions within the urban environment through the large scale projection of two sequences of actions skewed at 90 degree angles. Recorded in a deliberately anonymous and generic underground carpark and walkway and presented in slow motion, these sequences subtly reference visual cultural practices and spectatorship in an art historical context while engaged in a meditative study of contemporary activities of urban expression. In the first sequence, the camera follows a single BMX bicycle rider as they manoeuvre towards the darkened exit/entrance of a vast walkway, the bike and rider alike appearing to be pulled up and beyond the frame through the skewed presentation of the image. A loose translation of Caspar David Friedrich’s ‘Wanderer above the Sea of Fog’ (1818), the image stages the sublime position of the lone character in Friedrich’s painting in its representation of the BMX bicycle rider’s spatial orientation in and interaction with the contemporary urban landscape. Sequence two presents an aerial view of skateboarders falling into a tiled wall, some alone and others grouped together, with subtle reflections in composition on the geometry of Abstract art and the distant framing of imagery and figures in Western religious artworks. A layered soundscape of the sounds derived from the focal environment accompanies the projections to produce a low volume ambience for the on screen movements.

results.title: Gods Bones
results.creator_credit: Catherine Sinclair, Samantha Lang and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Angie is pregnant but who is the father? Is it the taxi-driver, the businessman, the actor or the medical student? The potential fathers-to-be are all in for an unexpected mail delivery - a letter with an unusual little parcel. A reminder of what could have been. Based on a short story by Yasunari Kawabata.
Cast: Olivia Pigeot, Brian Vriends, Bogdan Koga, Ritchie Singer, Kiri Paramore

results.title: Gods and monsters
results.creator_credit: Gregg Fienberg, Mark R. Harris, Bill Condon, Flashpoint Pictures, BBC Film Unit, Regent Entertainment and Paul Colichman
results.brief_description: Gods and Monsters is a biography of film director James Whale who created one of the screen’s great mythic heroes in the classic version of “Frankenstein”. Beginning in the 1950s when Whale (Ian McKellen) is largely forgotten or only remembered through camp nostalgia, the film traces Whale’s increasing obsession with his gardener, Clayton (Brendan Fraser). As Whale’s health deteriorates, his memory increasingly draws him back to the pivotal moments of his life: his rejection of his harsh working-class youth; his service in World War I and his loving affair with a fellow soldier; and his years directing in the classic Hollywood era. Combining biography and a mature examination of the possible love between homosexual and heterosexual men, “Gods and Monsters” ends up being a loving tribute to both the classic Hollywood era and the possibility of transcendence for working-class people. Based on the book “Father of Frankenstein” by Christopher Bram. Cast includes Ian McKellen, Brendan Fraser and Lynn Redgrave. (Awards: Winner of the 1998 Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gregg Fienberg, Mark R. Harris, Bill Condon, Flashpoint Pictures, BBC Film Unit, Regent Entertainment and Paul Colichman

results.title: Gods and men
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Grandeur that Was Rome”.
Famous British archaeologist Sir Mortimer Wheeler introduces the story of Christian influence on the degraded Roman Empire, with its cynical worship of gods. A message and belief was brought to spiritually empty Rome.

results.title: Godfathers and sons
results.creator_credit: Marc Levin, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. When immigrants from Poland and African Americans migrating north from the oppression of the south came together, some magic was made through music - in particular, the formation of Chess Records in 1950 - initially created by two Jewish brothers who were inspired listening to gospel music at a local church. Marc Levin looks at the history of blues by talking to the son of the founder of Chess, Marshall Chess and his take on music and inter-racial relations at the time. Marshall’s psychodelic inspired project Electric Mud featuring Muddy Waters is a pivotal album in the influential sphere of Chuck D from hip-hop’s Public Enemy. Exploring his roots, Chuck D, and Marshall, take a tour of Chicago and re-form the Electric Mud Group to pay homage to the ‘roots’ of blues and add their own contemporary interpretation. Marshall’s life in music went beyond the recording industry and he worked in the 1960s for seven years as Company Manager for the Rolling Stones. The take up of the blues by young white musicians in the UK and the US in the 1960s is shown - the cycle of Godfathers influencing the Sons. Features archival performance footage and includes live concert footage of the Chicago Blues Festival and the legendary Koko Taylor at her club. Howlin’ Wolf, Bob Dylan, Willie Dixon, Muddy Waters, Pinetop Perkins, and Ike Turner are some of the artists featured.

results.title: Goddess remembered
results.creator_credit: Magaret Pettigrew, Donna Read and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Women and spirituality”.
This stunning and poetic documentary is a salute to 35,000 years of pre-history, to the solid values of ancestors only recently remembered, and to our ancient goddess-worshipping religions. Archaeologists and anthropologists are beginning to discover evidence of a widespread early civilisation based primarily on human co-operation. This epsiode reveals these forgotten cultures - taking us from ancient caves in France to the sun-drenched palaces at Delphi and Crete. There is also a discussion among well-known scholars such as Merlin Stone and Jean Bolen, who propose a return to a belief in an interconnected life system, with respect for the earth and the female.

results.title: Godavari
results.creator_credit: Jehangir Bhownagary, Documentary Films of India and R.S. Junnerker
results.brief_description: A description of the River Godavari which flows from the hills east of Bombay across northern India to the Bay of Bengal. Includes an account of various temples, shrines, towns and villages built at its source and along its banks.
